Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of animal, possibly a deer or goat to right (part of torso with rib and belly remaining).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
According to Möller, the sherd dates to the Late Corinthian I period but she does not give a reason for such a late date.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 65, pl. 52, no. 230)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 222)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.199) (phase 3)
